worklogs.comment:
martinradev commented on pull request #6499: ARROW-7951: Expose BYTE_STREAM_SPLIT in pyarrow
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6499
 
 
   This patch exposes the new Parquet encoding in pyarrow.
   The decision is to always prefer the dictionary encoding if
   it set and to not have the BYTE_STREAM_SPLIT encoding by default.
   The reason for this is that the new encoding only improves
   compressibility for high-entropy data when combined with a compressor.
   Thus, it is useful only for certain cases.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6499#discussion_r386296723
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/_parquet.pyx
 ##########
 @@ -1334,6 +1339,15 @@ cdef class ParquetWriter:
             for column in self.use_dictionary:
                 props.enable_dictionary(column)
 
+    cdef void _set_byte_stream_split_props(
+            self, WriterProperties.Builder* props):
+        if isinstance(self.use_byte_stream_split, bool):
+            if self.use_byte_stream_split:
+                props.encoding(ParquetEncoding_BYTE_STREAM_SPLIT)
+        elif self.use_byte_stream_split is not None:
+            for column in self.use_dictionary:

     meaning for each codec, so you have to read the documentation of the
     codec you are using.
     An exception is thrown if the compression codec does not allow specifying
-    a compression level."""
+    a compression level.
+use_byte_stream_split: bool or list, default False
+    Specify if the byte_stream_split encoding should be used in general or
+    only for some columns. If both dictionary and byte_stream_stream are
+    enabled, then dictionary is prefered.
 
 Review comment:
   What does "prefered" mean here? Is dictionary tried until a certain cardinality and then it falls back on bytestream splitting?

 Review comment:
   After reading through the code, it is possible to check what information was propagated to the ColumnWriter but not what encoder object was created. That happens in the callstack
   TypedColumnWriterImpl
       MakeEncoder <------ this is where the final decision happens based on dictionary enablement, byte_stream_split_enablement, type.
   
   I am not able to find that one out without modifying the API and maybe it's not something which is necessary to check? I suppose it's up to the implementation to decide what it will use in the end as long as the parquet file is valid and results are ok.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6499#discussion_r387338889
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/_parquet.pyx
 ##########
 @@ -1334,6 +1339,15 @@ cdef class ParquetWriter:
             for column in self.use_dictionary:
                 props.enable_dictionary(column)
 
+    cdef void _set_byte_stream_split_props(
+            self, WriterProperties.Builder* props):
+        if isinstance(self.use_byte_stream_split, bool):
+            if self.use_byte_stream_split:
+                props.encoding(ParquetEncoding_BYTE_STREAM_SPLIT)
 
 Review comment:
   The current behavior is:
   If dictionary is used, then no exception is raised. The error gets generated when an attempt is made to create an byte_stream_split encoder for non-floating-point types.
   
   I extended my smoke test to check that an exception is thrown and propagated to pyarrow if integer data is attempted to be encoded using that encoding.

+                props.encoding(ParquetEncoding_BYTE_STREAM_SPLIT)

martinradev commented on pull request #6499: ARROW-7951: [Python] Expose BYTE_STREAM_SPLIT in pyarrow
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6499#discussion_r387341377
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/parquet.py
 ##########
 @@ -391,7 +391,13 @@ def _sanitize_table(table, new_schema, flavor):
     meaning for each codec, so you have to read the documentation of the
     codec you are using.
     An exception is thrown if the compression codec does not allow specifying
-    a compression level."""
+    a compression level.
+use_byte_stream_split: bool or list, default False
+    Specify if the byte_stream_split encoding should be used in general or
+    only for some columns. If both dictionary and byte_stream_stream are
+    enabled, then dictionary is prefered.
 
 Review comment:
   Dictionary will be selected regardless of whether byte_stream_split is enabled. The reason for this is that byte_stream_split actually only makes sense for high entropy data (like ~15 bits and higher per element), so one should be careful with selecting it.
   That's also currently the behavior in Parquet-MR but AFAIR the dictionary would fallback to byte_stream_split if it turns out that the dictionary does poorly according to some heuristic.
   
   To use byte_stream_split one would have to explicitly disable dictionary and enable byte_stream_split.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on pull request #6499: ARROW-7951: [Python] Expose BYTE_STREAM_SPLIT in pyarrow
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6499#discussion_r387562278
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_parquet.py
 ##########
 @@ -641,6 +641,36 @@ def make_sample_file(table_or_df):
     return pq.ParquetFile(buf)
 
 
+def test_byte_stream_split():
+    # This is only a smoke test.
+    arr_float = pa.array(list(map(float, range(100))))
+    data_float = [arr_float, arr_float]
+    table = pa.Table.from_arrays(data_float, names=['a', 'b'])
+
+    # Check with byte_stream_split for both columns.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=False, use_byte_stream_split=True)
+
+    # Check with byte_stream_split for column 'b' and dictionary
+    # for column 'a'.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=['a'],
+                     use_byte_stream_split=['b'])
+
+    # Check with a collision for both columns.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=['a', 'b'],
+                     use_byte_stream_split=['a', 'b'])
+
+    # Try to use the wrong data type with the byte_stream_split encoding.
+    # This should throw an exception.
+    arr_int = pa.array(list(map(int, range(10))))
+    table = pa.Table.from_arrays([arr_int], names=['tmp'])
+    with pytest.raises(IOError):
 
 Review comment:
   Why `IOError`? I would expect `ValueError`, since it's a parameter error.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

URL above to go to the specific comment.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6499#discussion_r387561867
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_parquet.py
 ##########
 @@ -641,6 +641,36 @@ def make_sample_file(table_or_df):
     return pq.ParquetFile(buf)
 
 
+def test_byte_stream_split():
+    # This is only a smoke test.
+    arr_float = pa.array(list(map(float, range(100))))
+    data_float = [arr_float, arr_float]
+    table = pa.Table.from_arrays(data_float, names=['a', 'b'])
+
+    # Check with byte_stream_split for both columns.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=False, use_byte_stream_split=True)
+
+    # Check with byte_stream_split for column 'b' and dictionary
+    # for column 'a'.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=['a'],
+                     use_byte_stream_split=['b'])
+
+    # Check with a collision for both columns.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=['a', 'b'],
+                     use_byte_stream_split=['a', 'b'])
+
+    # Try to use the wrong data type with the byte_stream_split encoding.
+    # This should throw an exception.
+    arr_int = pa.array(list(map(int, range(10))))
+    table = pa.Table.from_arrays([arr_int], names=['tmp'])
+    with pytest.raises(IOError):
+        _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, use_byte_stream_split=True,
 
 Review comment:
   Wouldn't it be more convenient for `use_byte_stream_split=True` to only apply to floating point columns? That way, if you have a table with e.g. 30 float columns and a bool columns, you don't have to enumerate the 30 float columns explicitly...
   
   The error should only be raised if you explicitly pass a column name that's not floating point.
   
   IOW, would be nice to have a test with mixed column types.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

martinradev commented on pull request #6499: ARROW-7951: [Python] Expose BYTE_STREAM_SPLIT in pyarrow
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6499#discussion_r390647757
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_parquet.py
 ##########
 @@ -641,6 +641,36 @@ def make_sample_file(table_or_df):
     return pq.ParquetFile(buf)
 
 
+def test_byte_stream_split():
+    # This is only a smoke test.
+    arr_float = pa.array(list(map(float, range(100))))
+    data_float = [arr_float, arr_float]
+    table = pa.Table.from_arrays(data_float, names=['a', 'b'])
+
+    # Check with byte_stream_split for both columns.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=False, use_byte_stream_split=True)
+
+    # Check with byte_stream_split for column 'b' and dictionary
+    # for column 'a'.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=['a'],
+                     use_byte_stream_split=['b'])
+
+    # Check with a collision for both columns.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=['a', 'b'],
+                     use_byte_stream_split=['a', 'b'])
+
+    # Try to use the wrong data type with the byte_stream_split encoding.
+    # This should throw an exception.
+    arr_int = pa.array(list(map(int, range(10))))
+    table = pa.Table.from_arrays([arr_int], names=['tmp'])
+    with pytest.raises(IOError):
 
 Review comment:
   This gets called https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/parquet/arrow/writer.cc#L481
   Parquet throws a ParquetException, Arrow captures it and returns an error.
   From the pyarrow check_status gets called which raises an IOError exception.
   
   Parquet also doesn't seem to expose anything but ParquetException and Arrow always consider failures to write a file as an IOError. Of course, we could do such validation on the pyarrow side but this doesn't really help with the Arrow interface.
   
   Do you think it's reasonable to leave it as IOError?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

martinradev commented on pull request #6499: ARROW-7951: [Python] Expose BYTE_STREAM_SPLIT in pyarrow
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6499#discussion_r390652633
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_parquet.py
 ##########
 @@ -641,6 +641,36 @@ def make_sample_file(table_or_df):
     return pq.ParquetFile(buf)
 
 
+def test_byte_stream_split():
+    # This is only a smoke test.
+    arr_float = pa.array(list(map(float, range(100))))
+    data_float = [arr_float, arr_float]
+    table = pa.Table.from_arrays(data_float, names=['a', 'b'])
+
+    # Check with byte_stream_split for both columns.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=False, use_byte_stream_split=True)
+
+    # Check with byte_stream_split for column 'b' and dictionary
+    # for column 'a'.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=['a'],
+                     use_byte_stream_split=['b'])
+
+    # Check with a collision for both columns.
+    _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, compression="gzip",
+                     use_dictionary=['a', 'b'],
+                     use_byte_stream_split=['a', 'b'])
+
+    # Try to use the wrong data type with the byte_stream_split encoding.
+    # This should throw an exception.
+    arr_int = pa.array(list(map(int, range(10))))
+    table = pa.Table.from_arrays([arr_int], names=['tmp'])
+    with pytest.raises(IOError):
+        _check_roundtrip(table, expected=table, use_byte_stream_split=True,
 
 Review comment:
   I think it's not a big deal in the case of python. I also think that the dictionary and plain encodings work similarly.
   Dictionary is enabled by default, but if one wants explicitly to use the plain encoding for some columns and dictionary for other ones, then one still has to specify a subset of the columns which would use one encoding or the other.
   I think it's better to explicitly select encodings which only make sense in specific scenarios. The byte_stream_split encodings only makes sense for high-entropy floating point data, and likely for integer data. The latter has to be checked.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

users@infra.apache.org

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description: The Parquet writer now supports the option of selecting the BYTE_STREAMS_SPLIT encoding. It could be nice to have it exposed in pyarrow.

comments.body:
+1. At the minimum pyarrow should be able to read Byte-stream-split encoded columns and display their encoding properly (add the required enum field conversion).

Also cc [~jorisvandenbossche]
